clinical_study.brief_title: Recombinant Human Granulocyte Monocyte - Colony Stimulating Factor (GM CSF) for Prevention of Pneumonia in Patients With Cirrhosis
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Trial of Recombinant Human Granulocye Monocyte - Colony Stimulating Factor (GM CSF) for Prevention of Pneumonia in Patients With Cirrhosis

lead_sponsor.agency: Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, India

clinical_study.source: Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences, India

brief_summary.textblock: Informed consent obtained from the patient or the patient's legal surrogate. The window for randomization and initiation of study drug infusion is 2 days from day of Admission. All further time points are relative to the day of randomization. Patients will be randomized (1:1) to receive either recombinant human GM-CSF or placebo. Using randomized block design of 10 each generated by computer and provided in sequential, sealed, opaque envelopes. Subjects will be stratified based on Child status. Patients who fulfil the inclusion criteria will receive either slow IV infusion of GM CSF (Sargamostatim-250mcg/M2) over 4 hour and inhalation of same dose by micronebulizer for 7 days OR Placebo(saline infusion and saline nebulization). Standard medical care will be given in both limbs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Development of extra pulmonary organ failure during the course of study.
Extra pulmonary Organ Failure will be defined as per Surviving sepsis guideline 2016

arm_group.description: GM CSF (Sargamostatim-250mcg/M2) over 4 hour and inhalation of same dose by micronebulizer OR Placebo for 7 days. Both the groups will receive standard medical care

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient with cirrhosis admitted to ICU-HDU without pneumonia at admission
- 18-70 years of Age
- Child B/ C
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient having pneumonia
- If there is evidence of preexisting chronic respiratory failure
- If the patients is neutropenic (absolute neutrophil count <1000 cells/mm3
- If there was a history of hematological malignancy or bone marrow transplantation
- Person having HCC
- Acute liver Failure
- Pregnancy
- HIV
